revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=July 2016}} '''''Biens mal acquis''''' ({{lang-fr|Ill-gotten goods}}) is a phrase used in French courts for [[litigation]] seeking the repayment of [[asset]]s stolen from poor countries by [[corrupt]] officials. The phrase refers to anti-corruption legal proceedings against former [[dictator]]s and [[Strongman (politics)|strongmen]] outside of their country, the [[seizure of assets]] within the country of the legal proceedings, and the return of the assets to their country they were [[embezzled]] from. ''Biens mal acquis'' is primarily used in France for its former colonies in the [[Françafrique]], but has since been used for similar cases filed in [[Spain]], [[Switzerland]] and [[Monaco]], and also against the [[Ferdinand Marcos|Marcos]] family and the estate of [[Sani Abacha]].
== ''Biens mal acquis'' == The phrase ''biens mal acquis'' is derived from the French [[proverb]] ''[[:fr:wikt:bien mal acquis ne profite jamais|bien mal acquis ne profite jamais]]'' meaning "a thing dishonorably obtained never truly enriches" in [[English language|English]], and is generally translated to the equivalent English phrase of "ill-gotten goods". In a March 2007 report by the [[Comité catholique contre la faim et pour le développement|Catholic Committee Against Hunger and for Development]] (CCFD), titled ''Biens mal acquis... profitent trop souvent. La fortune des dictateurs et les complaisances occidentales'' (English: Ill-Gotten Goods... Too Often Do Benefit: Western Complacency and the Wealth of Dictators), enumerates known instances of [[kleptocracy]] in [[Africa|African]] dictatorships, estimating that $100–180 billion in assets have been diverted by national leaders through [[embezzlement]] or unnecessary expenditure in recent decades.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ccfd-terresolidaire.org/IMG/pdf/BMA_totalBD.pdf |title=Biens mal acquis: à qui profite le crime? |date=June 2009 |publisher=CCFD-Terre Solidaire |editor=Catherine Gaudard |author1=Antoine Dulin |author2=Jean Merckaert |accessdate=June 6, 2016 |language=French }} </ref><ref>[http://www.ccfd.asso.fr/ewb_pages/i/info_999.php Rapport ''Biens mal acquis... profitent trop souvent!'']</ref> For example, [[Mobutu Sese Seko]], the [[President of Zaire|President]] of [[Zaire|Zaïre]] from 1965 until his death in 1997, became notorious for using his position as [[military dictator]] to openly embezzle massive sums of state money to fund an extravagant lifestyle. Mobutu had homes in France and Switzerland, and by the time of his death held a personal fortune of $5–6 billion, leaving his country with a [[public debt]] of $13 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9709/07/mobutu.wrap/ |title=Mobutu dies in exile in Morocco: Ruled Zaire with iron grip for 3 decades |date=September 7, 1997|publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://survie.org/billets-d-afrique/2007/162-octobre-2007/article/les-biens-mal-acquis-des-2889 |title=Les biens mal acquis des dictateurs africains|date=October 1, 2007|publisher=Survie}}</ref>
''Biens mal acquis'' was originally used in France for anti-corruption legal proceedings filed in its own [[judicial system]] against [[heads of state]] of the [[Françafrique]] accused of [[misappropriation|misappropriating]] or stealing state assets for their own benefit. The phrase became associated with corrupt politicians of these poor post-colonial countries, as they and their associates often invested their illegally-acquired fortunes in France. The term was later popularized for all litigation filed against any corrupt politicians of poor countries in any foreign judicial system, normally in [[Western Europe]], where the assets stolen by the defendant are believed to be held. Seized assets from former dictators found to have misappropriated treasury funds while in power have since been returned in [[restitution]] to the governments of the countries they were stolen from. Despite being the first [[G8]] country to ratify the [[United Nations Convention against Corruption]], known as the Mérida Convention, France has not undertaken any restitution measures. In other cases, judicial proceedings are still underway, or opposition groups have asked for the money to be returned in some other way to the country's people because a corrupt government is still in power. Sometimes this takes the form of a development project, with negotiated milestones for the release of funds.
The Belgian [[Centre national de coopération au développement]] (CNCD), or National Center for Cooperation in Development, has defined ''biens mal acquis'' as a "[[fixed asset|fixed]] or [[liquid asset|liquid]] asset or fund which may be misappropriated and illegally removed from the public heritage, and thereby impoverishing the state". Ill-gotten goods may result from [[tort]]ious or criminal activity, which has enabled heads of state to enrich themselves far beyond the level their official incomes can explain. Ill-gotten goods may stem from embezzlement, theft, or the illicit transfer of money from state to personal accounts, from [[corruption]] or from [[kickback (bribery)|kickbacks]]. Their owners often use opaque methods <!-- looking for better translation here, obfuscation maybe? And do we mean capital or business dealings? --> to hide their [[capital (economics)|capital]], assured of [[impunity]], particularly due to [[tax haven]]s, and also assured of the complacency of [[developed nations]].
== List of assets seized== This section is a list of known assets successfully seized through ''biens mal acquis'' rulings and is incomplete:
===Gabon=== Gabonese president [[Ali Bongo Ondimba]] is estimated to have paid €98 million to the {{Interlanguage link multi|Pozzo di Borgo|fr|3=Famille Pozzo di Borgo}} family for the Soyecourt, an historic [[hôtel particulier]] on the [[Rue de l'Université (Paris)|rue de l'Université]] in the [[7th arrondissement of Paris|7th arrondissement]] in central [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latribune.fr/vos-finances/immobilier/20110413trib000615225/ces-palais-qui-se-vendent-plus-de-100-millions-d-euros-a-paris.html |date=April 13, 2011|title=Ces palais qui se vendent plus de 100 millions d'euros à Paris}}</ref>
{{glossary}}<!-- image files of primary sources for this section exist @ french wikipedia and need to be imported still. Need secondary sources but they definitely exist, maybe even in English --><!-- a Google search for the title of this wikipedia article currently surfaces a more extensive list in a publicly-available Google Document. I have not examined it in any detail but it contains additional names and may be importable as a table. It gives a source for each asset seizure. It does not appear to be labeled with its provenance but this may be ascertainable. --trans --> '''''[[Gabon]] - Assets seized from the family of [[Omar Bongo Ondimba|Omar Bongo]]'''''<ref name="ReferenceA"> Data published by ''La Tribune'' December 3, 2008, and originating from the investigation of the ''[[Office central de la répression de la grande délinquance financière]]'' following the March 2007 complaint brought by three French non-profits.</ref> *'''Audrey Blanche Bongo Odimba''' **rue de Longchamp, 92200 [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]] **500m² 4-room apartment with garage and basement *'''[[Edith Lucie Bongo|Édith Lucie Sassou]]''' - wife of President [[Omar Bongo]] from 1990 to 2009, daughter of [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]], President of the [[Republic of the Congo]]. **avenue Rapp, 75007 Paris, 4-room apartment **avenue Rapp, 75007 Paris, 4-room apartment, 342m² **avenue Rapp, 75007 Paris, 4 room apartment, 284m² **rue du Mont-Boron, [[Nice]], France *'''[[Jean Ping]]''' - politician and [[Chairperson of the Commission of the African Union]] from 2008 to 2012, formerly married to Omar Bongo's eldest daughter, Pascaline. **rue Quentin-Bauchart, 75008 Paris **avenue d’Italie, 75013 Paris *'''Jeff Thierry Arsène Jaffar Bongo Ondimba''' - son of President Ali Bongo Ondimba **Aix-en-Provence, 125m² apartment with 13 garages, purchased 2005, value €1.24 million<ref name=LDjeff>{{cite news|title=Enquête sur la fortune de trois présidents africains: International: La Justice française enquête sur le train de vie des chefs d'état du Congo, du Gabon et de la Guinée équatoriale|url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2009/05/07/603144-enquete-sur-la-fortune-de-trois-presidents-africains.html|date=July 5, 2009|language=French|work=ladepeche.fr|accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> **Villeneuve-Loubet, house **avenue Raymond-Poincarré, 75016 Paris, 4-room apartment **also: 2 apartments in downtown Nice, 100 and 170 m², three houses just off the [[Promenade des Anglais]]<ref name=LDjeff /> *'''Omar Ben Bongo''' - father of President [[Ali Bongo]] **bd Lannes, 75016 Paris, 7-room apartment *'''Omar Bongo Ondimba''' - President of Gabon since October 2009 **bd Frédéric-Sterling, Nice France, 8-room house, 215m² **bd Frédéric-Sterling, Nice France, 7-room apartment, 170 m² <ref name=Prov>{{cite news|url=http://www.provence-guide.fr/provence-le-scandale-des-palaces-provencaux-du-clan-bongo.html|title=Le scandale des palaces provençaux du clan Bongo |date=June 9, 2009 |work=Le Guide de la Provence}}</ref> **bd Frédéric-Sterling Nice, France, 6-room apartment, 100m²<ref name=Prov /> **rue Edmond-Valentin, 75007 Paris, **avenue Foch, 75016 Paris, 4-room apartment **avenue Foch, 75016 Paris, 3-room apartment, 88m² **avenue Foch, 75016 Paris, 5-room apartment, 210m² **avenue Foch, 75016 Paris, 9-room apartment, 365 m² **bd Flandrin, 75016 Paris **rue de Longchamp, 75016 Paris **avenue Raymond-Poincaré, 75016 Paris **rue Leroux, 75016 Paris **rue Laurent-Pichat, 75016 Paris, apartment, 219m² *'''[[Omar Bongo]]''' - President of Gabon from 1967 to 2009, father of current President Omar Bongo Ondimba. <!-- linking a second time because the first one was pretty far up --> **rue de la Tremoille, 75008 Paris **rue de la Faisanderie, 75016 Paris **allée des Feuillantines, 94000 Villejuif, France *'''Yacine Queenie Bongo Odimba''' **rue de la Baume, 75008 Paris, [[hôtel particulier]] **bd Lannes, 75016 Paris **bd Suchet, 75016 Paris
===Republic of the Congo=== '''[[Republic of the Congo]] - Assets seized from the family of [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]]'''<ref name="ReferenceA" /> *'''Denis Sassou Nguesso''' declares that he does not have a bank account in his name in France. Still, the investigation by the [[Office central de répression de la grande délinquance financière]], found 112 bank accounts registered to members of his family. **avenue Rapp, 75007 **villa at [[Vésinet]] **rue Marbeuf, 75008 Paris, 7-room apartment *'''Julienne Sassou Nguesso''' **bd Saint-Denis, 92400 Courbevoie, 8 rooms, 175m² **bd du Général Koenig, 92200 Neuilly-sur-Seine, 7-room [[Hôtel particulier]] with inside swimming pool *'''Claudia Lemboumba''' **avenue Victor-Hugo, 75016 Paris, Studio **rue Copernic, 75016 Paris, 6-room apartment with 2 ''[[Chambre de bonne|chambres de bonne]]'' **avenue Turgot, 93700 Drancy, France, 6-room house *'''Maurice Nguesso''' **rue Poirier-Fourrier, 95100 Argenteuil, 4-room apartment **villa Rochefort, 91000 Évry, France, 3-room apartment **bd Malesherbes, 75008 Paris *'''Antoinette Tchibo Malonda''', wife of Sassou N’Guesso **avenue Niel, 75017 Paris. 9-room apartment, 328m², bought for €2.47 million in 2007<ref>{{cite web|title=image|url=http://dossierssignales.blogs.nouvelobs.com/media/00/00/918204319.jpg}}</ref> **8 bank accounts (stockbroker and checking accounts) at [[Crédit Industriel et Commercial]] (CIC) and at the [[Crédit Lyonnais]], in Paris and Boulogne-Billancourt<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dossierssignales.blogs.nouvelobs.com/media/00/00/184441711.jpg|title=Subpoena: Antoinette Tchibo Malonda bank accounts}}</ref> *'''Denis Christel Sassou Nguesso''' **rue de la Tour, 75016 Paris. 10-room with garage and ''chambre de service'' *'''[[Claude Wilfrid Etoka]], as trustee for Denis Christel Sassou Nguesso''' : **SARPD Oil, USD 500 million *'''Wilfrid Nguesso''' : **[[Mercedes Benz S Class|Mercedes S500]], €107,400 **[[Mercedes-Benz M-Class|ML63 AMG]], €116,000 **[[Aston Martin DB9]], €172,321<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dossierssignales.blogs.nouvelobs.com/media/01/00/572987024.jpg|title=image}}</ref> **[[Audi Q7]], €65,000 **[[Land Rover]], €95,000 **[[Mercedes Benz G-Class|Mercedes G55 AMG]], €90,000 **[[Aston Martin]], DB7 Vantage €77,000 **[[BMW X5]], €75,800 **[[Porsche Cayenne]], €67,952 **[[Toyota Land Cruiser]], €40,000
===Equatorial Guinea=== '''[[Equatorial Guinea]] - Assets seized from the family of [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo|Teodoro Obiang]]'''<ref name="ReferenceA"/> *'''[[Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue|Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangué]]''' - [[Vice President of Equatorial Guinea]] and son of [[President of Equatorial Guinea]] Teodoro Obiang. **[[Bugatti Veyron]], €1,196,000 **Bugatti-Veyron, €1,196,000 **Bugatti-Veyron, €1,196,000 **[[Enzo Ferrari (automobile)|Ferrari Enzo]], €675,000 **[[Maserati MC12]], €709,000 **[[Maybach 57 and 62|Maybach 62]], €510,479 **[[Rolls Royce Phantom]] Limousine, €381,000 **[[Maserati Coupé]] F1 Cambiocorsa, €82,000 **[[Ferrari Testarossa|Ferrari Type 512 M]], €182,938 **[[Ferrari 550]] Maranello, €152,201 {{glossary end}}
== List of restitutions == This sections is a known list of restitutions made by ''biens mal acquis'' rulings and is incomplete:
[[Switzerland]] has made several restitutions: * $658 million<!-- US presumably? --> returned to the [[Philippines]] in 2003 after 17 years of [[litigation]] in the Philippines over the estate of the late former president [[Ferdinand Marcos]].<ref>{{cite book|page=92|author1=Mark Pieth|publisher=Peter Lang|date=2008|title=Recovering Stolen Assets|isbn=3039115839|via=Google Books|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Twdt0VF-ML8C|accessdate=June 1, 2016}}</ref> * $2.4 million from the [[Mali]]an dictator [[Moussa Traoré]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://star.worldbank.org/corruption-cases/node/18555|title=Moussa Traore|work=Stolen Asset Recovery Initiative|publisher=World Bank|accessdate=June 1, 2016}}</ref> * Switzerland gave back $380 million (£260 million) in restitution to [[Nigeria]] in March 2015 from the estate of former dictator [[Sani Abacha]], who held much of an embezzled $2.2 billion fortune in Swiss bank accounts in his name.<ref name=GuardSwiss> {{cite web |title=Switzerland to return Sani Abacha 'loot' money to Nigeria: European banks held the bulk of up to $2.2bn which the Nigerian dictator stole from his country during his five-year rule |work=The Guardian |author=David Smith |date=March 15, 2015|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/18/switzerland-to-return-sani-abacha-loot-money-to-nigeria |accessdate=June 1, 2016 }} </ref> Switzerland had previously returned $700m to Nigeria from Abacha's Swiss accounts in the first restitution of its kind.<ref name=GuardSwiss /> * $80 million diverted by the family of [[Peru|Peruvian]] president [[Alberto Fujimori]], who was convicted of corruption in 2015. Fujimori had already gotten a 25-year-sentence in 2009 for ordering the deaths of twenty people in 2005, and the sentence for embezzlement will run concurrent to his murder sentence(s).<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/09/world/americas/peru-jailed-ex-president-is-convicted-of-corruption.html |title=<nowiki></nowiki>Peru: Jailed Ex-President Is Convicted of Corruption |date=January 8, 2015 |author=William Neumann |work=World Briefing |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 13, 2016 }} </ref><!-- verify that plural is appropriate -->
The [[United Kingdom]] has also returned to Nigeria funds that Sani Abacha had sheltered in [[Jersey]] in the [[Channel Islands]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/features/the-big-read-the-dark-side-of-a-golden-isle-257278.html |title=THE BIG READ: The dark side of a golden isle|author= Leah McGrath Goodman |date=February 1, 2014|publisher=Irish Examiner}}</ref>
Following the [[Iraq War]] in 2003, the [[United States]] and its allies seized more than $2 billion from the family of [[Iraq]]i dictator [[Saddam Hussein]], the single largest restitution to date, which was slated to be used to rebuild Iraq.{{dubious|date=June 2016}}.
==Current restitution proceedings==
===Spain=== In May 2009, the [[Spain|Spanish]] anti-corruption prosecutor requested a money-laundering investigation of the accounts and investments in Spain of the president of Equatorial Guinea, Teodoro Obiang, following a complaint filed in December 2008 by the Asociacion pro derechos humanos de España (APDHE). The association was concerned by a transfer of roughly €19 million between 2000 and 2003 from the US bank [[Riggs Bank]] to an account in a Spanish bank in the [[Balearic Islands]].<ref>http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/fr_fr/noticias/africa/parquet-espagnol-pour-une-enquete-sur-les-comptes-president-Obiang,c658bf06-30c7-4f32-a388-aa01cadb69ad.html</ref>
===France=== {{Quote box |class = <!-- Advanced users only. See the "Custom classes" section below. --> |title = |quote = It is unacceptable that while the nation became impoverished some enriched themselves at her expense |author = |source = |align = right |width = 20% |border = 1px |fontsize = 24 |bgcolor = |style = |title_bg = |title_fnt = |tstyle = |qalign = left |qstyle = y |quoted = |salign = |sstyle = }} Laws put into effect after the liberation of France in the [[Second World War]] targeted illegitimate profits accrued during [[German occupation of France|German occupation]], in the [[black market]] or through simple theft. The ordinances of October 18, 1944 and January 6, 1945 drew inspiration from the following principle: "The most elementary fiscal justice requires that all gains made possible by the presence of the enemy be returned to the public treasury. It is unacceptable that while the nation became impoverished some enriched themselves at its expense."<ref> {{cite book |title=Les patrons sous l'Occupation |author1=Renaud de Rochebrune |author2=Jean-Claude Hazera |publisher=Odile Jacob |page=328 |date=March 21, 2013 |via=Google Books |isbn=2738129382}}</ref>
Citing this precedent, in March 2007 [[Survie]], the [[Sherpa (association)|Sherpa Association]] and the Fédération des Congolais de la Diaspora filed charges of conspiracy and concealment of diversion of funds in the [[Tribunal d'instance|Tribunal de Grande Instance]] in Paris against five heads of African states and their families: *Omar Bongo Ondimba (Gabon), *Denis Sassou Nguesso (Republic of Congo) *[[Blaise Compaoré]] ([[Burkina Faso]]) *[[José Eduardo dos Santos|Eduardo Dos Santos]] ([[Angola]]) *Teodoro Obiang (Equatorial Guinea)
The three [[NGO]] organizations suspected these heads or former heads of state of buying up a surprising number of luxury real estate assets in France, and of holding banking assets in French banks and/or foreign banks doing business in France. An investigation opened in June 2007 was characterized as insufficiently detailed and suspended in November 2007.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://rue89.nouvelobs.com/2007/11/27/dictateurs-africains-biens-mal-acquis-pas-poursuivis-4389 |title=''Dictateurs africains: biens mal acquis, pas poursuivis'' |trans-title=African dictators: Ill-gotten goods, not pursued |work=Rue89 Droit de suite |date=2007-11-27 |language=French |accessdate=July 14, 2016 }} </ref> The French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'' obtained transcripts for the hearing into whether to pursue the investigation and in January 2008 published a list of dozens of real estate properties owned by family members of Sassou Nguesso and Omar Bongo in Paris and in the south of France, some of them worth millions of euros. Maître William Bourdon of Survie, the plaintiffs' legal representation, denounced the decision to close the case as "astounding" (''ahurissant'')<ref> {{cite news |url=tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/societe/20110609.OBS4836/biens-mal-acquis-le-parquet-refuse-d-etendre-l-enquete.html |title=Biens mal acquis: le parquet refuse d'étendre l'enquête |trans-title=Court Refuses to Continue Investigation |work=[[Le Nouvel Observateur]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] }} </ref> The family of Omar Bongo Ondimba, according to the ''Le Monde'' hearing transcripts, owned 33 apartments or houses including a ''hôtel particulier'' in Paris worth more than €18 million. The ''hôtel particulier'' was purchased in June 2007 by a real estate company associated with two children of the Gabonese president, then aged 13 and 16. The family of Sassou Nguesso owned at least 18 apartments or houses in France.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2008/12/03/avenue-foch-j-achete_1005826_3212.html |title=Avenue Foch, j'achète ! |date=3 December 2008 |publisher= |accessdate=2 July 2016 |website=Le Monde }} </ref> In Gabon, an association christened ''Touche pas à mon président'' (Don't touch my president) was formed in July 2008 to protest the NGOs denouncing the real estate assets of Omar Bongo.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.afriquecentrale.info/central.php?o=5&s=39&d=3&i=1802 |title=Crédits, assurances, placements |publisher= |accessdate=2 July 2016 |df= }}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} </ref>
On December 2, 2008, [[Transparency International]] France, the Sherpa Association, and a Gabonese citizen named Grégory Ngbwa Mintsa filed new charges against Omar Bongo, Denis Sassou Nguesso and Teodoro Obiang as well as their entourages, of concealing the embezzlement of public funds.
[[Patrick Maisonneuve]], the lawyer for Omar Bongo, announced the same day that a defamation complaint would be filed based on the allegations of embezzlement, intimidation and corruption, but as of May 2009 no such complaint had been filed.<ref>http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/depeches/topnews_reuters/20090505.REU8224/un_juge_francais_ouvre_une_enquete_sur_3_chefs_detat_af.html{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On December 5 Congolese government spokesman Alain Akouala Atipault announced that the Congo had filed a complaint in the [[Tribunal d'instance|Tribunal de grande instance]] of Paris against Transparency International France and Sherpa. "I have simply decided that my lawyer in Paris will pursue these gentlemen (TI and Sherpa), who are in reality a few [[bourgeois]] in [[Neuilly-sur-Seine|Neuilly]] who may never even have set foot in the Congo", declared Sassou Nguesso.<ref> {{cite news |agency=AFP |title=Patrimoine. Les plaignants sont des "bourgeois de Neuilly" (Sassou Nguesso) |date=10 December 2008 |trans-title=}}</ref> On December 31, 2008, Grégory Ngbwa Mintsa, a party to the complaint in France, was questioned and imprisoned for "possession of a document with intent to distribute it for propaganda purposes" and "oral or written propaganda with intent to incite revolt against the authorities," with, on January 7, three leaders of a Gabonese NGO and a journalist<!-- verify against reference, confusing because no prior mention of a Gabonese NGO --> as a result of a complaint filed by Fondation Omar Bongo.<ref>[http://www.lejdd.fr/cmc/scanner/international/200902/gabon-des-responsables-d-ong-arretes_176923.html?popup Gabon:] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120803141851/http://www.lejdd.fr/cmc/scanner/international/200902/gabon-des-responsables-d-ong-arretes_176923.html?popup# |date=2012-08-03 }} Des responsables d'ONG arrêtés jdd.fr 6 janvier 2009</ref> On January 8, {{Interlanguage link multi|Thierry Lévy|fr}}, lawyer for the Gabonese, was prevented by the border police at [[Roissy Airport]] in Paris from boarding a plane for a flight to [[Libreville]], his four-day [[travel visa |visa]] having been cancelled by the Gabonese authorities "for security reasons".<ref>[http://www.rue89.com/2009/01/08/arrestations-au-gabon-me-levy-empeche-de-se-rendre-a-libreville] Arrestations au Gabon : Me Levy empêché de se rendre à Libreville rue89.com 8 janvier 2009</ref> The conditional release of the four on January 12 was accompanied by a ''mandat de dépôt''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gaboneco.com/show_article.php?IDActu=11807# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-06-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821150029/http://gaboneco.com/show_article.php?IDActu=11807# |archive-date=2013-08-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
January 20, 2009 the Congolese journalist [[Bruno Ossébi]], who had expressed the intention of joining the complaint, was the victim of a fire at his home in [[Brazzaville]] where he, his girlfriend and her two children died in the fire.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.temoignagechretien.fr/journal/article.php?num=3333&categ=FranceEurope |title=Françafrique: incendies chez des opposants congolais Témoignage Chrétien |date=January 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211030119/http://www.temoignagechretien.fr/journal/article.php?num=3333&categ=FranceEurope |archivedate=2009-02-11 |df= }}</ref> Bruno Ossébi suffered second-degree burns but had been recovering when he died suddenly February 2 in Brazzaville.<ref name=LMOss>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2009/07/09/la-mort-mysterieuse-d-un-journaliste-franco-congolais-a-brazzaville_1217113_3212.html|title=La mort mystérieuse d'un journaliste franco-congolais à Brazzaville|author=Philippe Bernard|language=French|work=Le Monde|date=September 7, 2009|accessdate=June 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>http://mobile.lemonde.fr/depeche/38342050.html{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to [[Reporters without Borders]], who said it was "probable" that the fire was a deliberate attack,<ref name=LMOss /> Ossḗbi had three days earlier published an article on the online news site Mwinga alleging that the national petroleum corporation, managed by the president's son, had approached a French bank about a $100 million loan secured by its oil production, in contravention of Congo's pledges to the [[International Monetary Fund]].<ref name=LMOss /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://rsf.org/en/reports/report-investigation-franco-congolese-journalists-death|title=Report of investigation into Franco-Congolese journalist's death|date=July 9, 2009|author=Reporters without Borders| accessdate=June 1, 2016}}</ref> He had made contact with the Stolen Goods Recovery Initiative at the World Bank, just two days earlier.<ref name=LMOss /> The day after Ossébi's death, a fire also broke out at the [[Orleans|Orléans]] home of Benjamin Toungamani, who in the previous December filed a complaint with French police against unknown persons because of death threats against his family.<ref>http://www.mediapart.fr/journal/france/081208/plaintes-menaces-l-enquete-qui-affole-omar-bongo-et-d-autres-dirigeants-africa Plaintes, menaces: l'enquête qui affole Omar Bongo et d'autres dirigeants africains Médiapart.fr</ref> At the request of the prosecution, the decision in this case, scheduled for the end of February, was pushed back until after the visit of French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] to the Republic of the Congo at the end of March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dossierssignales.blogs.nouvelobs.com/archive/2009/03/17/comment-e-tile-parquet-tente-de-sauver-bongo.html|title=Comment le Parquet tente de sauver Bongo - République bananière|trans-title=How the Parquey tries to save Bongo -- Banana Republic|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref>
May 5, 2009, the most senior investigating judge in Paris, Françoise Desset, agreed to hear the case, a decision the prosecutor appealed.<ref> {{cite web |title=Paris judge to examine African leaders' finances |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/paris-judge-to-examine-african-leaders-finances-1680808.html |author=John Lichfield |date=May 7, 2009 |work=The Independent |accessdate=June 1, 2013 }} </ref><ref>https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hxc-4GG2MhpKeCzDHTlHJh5q2tLw Dépêche AFP 5 mai 2009</ref> On October 29, 2009, the Paris court of appeal upheld the Ministry and found that Transparency International lacked standing. Following the association's appeal the French [[Court of Cassation (France)|Court of Cassation]], the court of final appeal, on November 9, 2010 found that Transparency International could participate in the suit, henceforth allowing a French examining magistrate to investigate.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/actualite/monde/20101026.OBS1862/biens-mal-acquis-decision-de-la-cour-de-cassation-le-9-novembre.html |title=Biens mal acquis: décision de la Cour de Cassation le 9 novembre|publisher= |accessdate=2 July 2016 }} </ref>
A February 2011 alert from Tracfin, the money-laundering unit of the French finance ministry, mentioned a purchase by Obiang's son of €18 million worth of [[fine art]] in February 2009 alone. On October 6, 2011, Transparency International France and Sherpa Association announced a new complaint in civil court to circumvent the block by the prosecutor's office, which had been refusing an indictment needed for the examining magistrates to deal with new facts discovered in the course of their investigation. On July 12, 2012, the examining magistrates in charge of the investigation issued an international [[Interpol notice|arrest warrant]] for Teodorin Nguema Obiang following his refusal to appear. For Maud Perdriel-Vaissière, director of Sherpa, this step demonstrated "the seriousness of the allegations Sherpa has been making from the first [...] and show that nobody should believe themselves above law. From now on, immunity is no longer a synonym of impunity".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2012/07/13/mandat-d-arret-contre-le-fils-du-president-de-guinee-equatoriale_1733405_3212.html|title=Mandat d'arrêt contre le fils du président de Guinée équatoriale|work=LeMonde.fr|date=13 July 2012}}</ref>
March 19, 2014 the [[examining magistrate|juges d'instruction]] of the Tribunal de Grande Instance de Paris indicted Teodorin Nguema Obiang for money-laundering.
===Monaco=== {{wiktionary|nominee}} On March 30, 2009, [[Monaco]] opened an investigation into accounts in the name of [[Édith Bongo]], who died March 14, 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20090315-omar-bongos-wife-edith-lucie-ondimba-dies-morocco|title=Omar Bongo's wife Edith dies in Morocco|date=March 15, 2009|work=France 24}}</ref> Bongo was suspected of having acted as nominee in several banking establishments for both her husband and father, the presidents of Gabon and Republic of the Congo, respectively, in order to mask assets obtained with diverted funds. The investigation was opened following a letter from the Sherpa Association to Prince [[Albert II of Monaco|Albert II]] and to the prosecutor of Monaco, requesting an investigation and the freezing of Édith Bongo's financial assets in Monaco.<ref>Dépêche AFP 31 mars 2009 Ouverture d'une enquête sur des comptes qui appartiendraient à Edith Bongo à Monaco https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5geKpOB0CMoEoHW3rkVS6XtSMlNeQ</ref>
===Switzerland=== On April 30, 2009, Switzerland extended the freezing of 8.3 million Swiss francs in an account in Mobutu Sese Seko,'s name, originally instituted on May 17, 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/DEPAFP20090225T171004Z/Index_Dossiers|title=La Suisse prolonge à nouveau le gel des avoirs de Mobutu - JeuneAfrique.com|date=25 February 2009|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref> On February 12, 2009, the federal office of the Swiss justice system ordered the restitution to [[Haiti]] of 7 million Swiss francs (€4.6 million) frozen in Swiss bank accounts since 1986, to finance development projects. Former Haitian dictator [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]] filed an appeal of this decision on March 19, 2009.<ref>Genève (AWP/AFP) http://www.romandie.com/infos/news2/200903191912040AWPCH.asp</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox recurring event |name=Bud Billiken Parade and Picnic |logo=Bud_Billiken_Logo.jpg |logo_caption = |image= |image_size = |caption= |location=35th–55th Streets and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Drive
([[Douglas, Chicago|Bronzeville]]/[[Grand Boulevard, Chicago|Grand Boulevard]]/[[Washington Park, Chicago (community area)|Washington Park]])
[[Chicago, Illinois]] | country = United States | years_active = {{start date|1929}}–present{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-bud-billiken-parade-2017-if-you-go-htmlstory.html |title= Bud Billiken Parade 2017 - If you go... |author=Chicago Tribune |date=August 11, 2017|website= Chicago Tribune |publisher= Chicago Tribune}}[https://books.google.com/books?id=eV45DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT180&dq=bud+billiken+parade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiI8a-e_dnVAhXM34MKHSLrDK4Q6AEIYDAK#v=onepage&q=bud%20billiken%20parade&f=false Encyclopedia of African American Society, Volume 1 - Bud Billiken Day Parade - By Gerald D. Jaynes] | next = August 10, 2019 | status = Active |genre= Parade |website= {{URL|budbillikenparade.org}} |founder_name = [[Robert Sengstacke Abbott|Robert S. Abbott]] (Founder) | frequency = Annual }} The '''Bud Billiken Parade and Picnic''' (also known as The '''Bud Billiken Day Parade''') is an annual [[parade]] held since 1929[https://books.google.com/books?id=oW3JAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA53&dq=bud+billiken+parade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi9uayz_dnVAhWF6YMKHZZUBQw4HhDoAQgyMAI#v=onepage&q=bud%20billiken%20parade&f=false The Regal Theater and Black Culture - By C. Semmes] in [[Chicago, Illinois]], United States; it is the largest [[African-American]] parade in the nation. Held annually on the second Saturday in August,Jerald Walker, "Dreams From My Father," ''Mother Jones,'' January/February 2009, p. 53 The parade route travels through the [[Douglas, Chicago|Bronzeville]] and [[Washington Park, Chicago (community area)|Washington Park]]{{cite web |url=http://wgntv.com/2017/08/12/annual-bud-billiken-parade-brings-best-of-chicago-together/ |title=Bud Billiken Parade Brings Best of Chicago Together|date=August 12, 2017 |website= WGN 9 Chicago |publisher= WGN |access-date=August 19, 2017|quote=}} neighborhoods on the city's south side. [[Robert S. Abbott]], the founder and publisher of the ''[[Chicago Defender]],'' created the fictional character of Bud Billiken, which he featured in a column in his paper. David Kellum, co-founder of the [[Bud Billiken Club]] and longtime parade coordinator{{cite web |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1981/03/21/David-Kellum-the-legendary-Bud-Billiken-died-in-Rush/6250353998800/ |title=David Kellum, The Legendary "Bud Billiken" died in Rush|date=March 21, 1981 |website= UPI |publisher= |access-date=August 19, 2017|quote=}}{{cite web |url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=146890965|title=David W. Kellum (1903-1981)|website= Find A Grave |publisher= |access-date=August 19, 2017 |quote=}}{{cite web |url=https://chicagodefender.com/2008/08/05/bud-billiken-parade-history-how-it-all-got-started/ |title=Bud Billiken Parade History: How It All Got Started|date=August 5, 2008 |website= Chicago Defender |publisher= |access-date= August 19, 2017 |quote=}} suggested the parade as a celebration of African-American life. Since its beginning, the parade has featured celebrities, politicians, businessmen, civic organizations and youth. It is considered the second largest parade in the United States,{{cite web |url=http://abc7chicago.com/family/abc7s-broadcast-of-the-bud-billiken-parade/894144/|title=Broadcast of The Bud Billiken Parade|date= August 7, 2015|website= ABC 7 Chicago |publisher=ABC Inc., WLS-TV Chicago |access-date=August 19, 2017 |quote=}}{{cite web |url=https://chicagodefender.com/2015/08/09/bud-billiken-pulls-the-crowd/ |title=Bud Billiken Pulls The Crowd |date=August 9, 2015 |website= |publisher=Chicago Defender |access-date=August 19, 2017 |quote=}}{{Cite web|url=http://abc7chicago.com/family/abc7s-broadcast-of-the-bud-billiken-parade/894144/|accessdate=August 14, 2007|date=2006|title=ABC 7 Chicago Presents Live Broadcast Of The Bud Billiken Parade|publisher=ABC Inc., WLS-TV Chicago}}{{cite web |url=https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/parade27.html |title= Bud Billiken Parade|date=2007 |website= |publisher= City of Chicago |access-date=August 19, 2017|quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/bud-billiken-parade-brings-folk-out |title= Historic Events/Bud Billiken Parade |date= |website= |publisher=Aaregistry |access-date=August 20, 2017 |quote=}} whose focus is on celebrating youth, education and African-American life. The parade is also cited as the "back-to-school" celebration, marking the end of summer vacation and resuming of school for Chicago's youth.{{cite web |url=https://www.timeout.com/chicago/blog/the-bud-billiken-parade-was-a-joyous-back-to-school-celebration-081317 |title=The Bud Billiken Parade was a joyous back-to-school celebration|date=August 13, 2017 |website= TimeOut |publisher= |access-date=August 20, 2017 |quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/chi-billiken-parade-celebrates-youth-education-20120811-story.html |title=Billiken Parade Celebrates Youth, Education |date=August 11, 2012 |website= ABC 7 Chicago |publisher= |access-date=August 20, 2017 |quote=}}{{cite web | last = Scott | first = Eugene F. | title = From the Colonel | publisher = Bud Billiken Parade | url = http://www.budbillikenparade.org/from-the-colonel | accessdate = August 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140727053724/http://www.budbillikenparade.org/from-the-colonel | archivedate = July 27, 2014 | df = mdy-all }} ==History== [[File:BUD_BILLIKEN_DAY_PARADE_AS_IT_TRAVELS_CHICAGO'S_SOUTH_SIDE_ON_DR._MARTIN_L._KING_JR._DRIVE._ONE_OF_THE_LARGEST_EVENTS..._-_NARA_-_556274.jpg|thumb|right|Chicago Department of Human Resource float in the 1973 parade. Photo by [[John H. White (photojournalist)|John H. White]].]] [[File:20040814 Bud Billiken Obama float.JPG|thumb|left|[[Barack Obama]] float for [[United States Senate election in Illinois, 2004|2004 U.S. Senate race]] in the 2004 parade.]] [[File:20040814 Bud Billiken Miss Black IL.JPG|thumb|right|Miss Black Illinois in the 2004 parade.]] [[File:US Navy 080809-N-9056L-053 Sailors from Navy Band Great Lakes march in the 79th annual Bud Billiken parade, kicking off the 2008 Chicago Navy Week events.jpg|thumb|left|U.S. Navy band marches in the 2008 parade.]] [[File:Billiken2008HighSchoolAntiViolenceAcrobats.jpg|thumb|right|Anti-violence group for a Chicago high school in the 2008 parade.]] [[File:Billiken2008HawksSaxes.jpg|thumb|right|[[Hillcrest High School (Country Club Hills, Illinois)|Hillcrest High School]] marching band in the 2008 parade.]] Bud Billiken is a [[fictional character]] created in 1923 by Abbott, who had been considering adding a youth section to the ''[[Chicago Defender]]'' newspaper. While dining at a Chinese restaurant he noticed a [[Billiken]]. Some of the early Billiken columns were written by [[Willard Motley]], who later became a prominent novelist. During the early 1930s, names of international youth were listed in the "Bud Billiken" section of the newspaper every week. Between 1930–34, approximately 10,000 names appeared and were archived in the Carter G. Woodson Regional Library of the [[Chicago Public Library]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.8thinfantry.org/billiken.html|accessdate=July 4, 2007|title=Bud Billiken Parade|publisher=8th Infantry Illinois National Guard Association|date=}} During the [[Great Depression]], Abbott featured the Bud Billiken character in his newspaper as a symbol of pride, happiness and hope for black residents.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jessejacksonjr.org/issues/i0812025939.html|accessdate=July 4, 2007|title=What's In A Name? More Than A Parade|author=Pierre, Robert E.|publisher=Jesse Jackson, Jr. for Congress|work=The Washington Post|date=August 12, 2002|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928040651/http://www.jessejacksonjr.org/issues/i0812025939.html |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The character gained prominence in a comic strip and the ''Chicago Defender'' newspaper. Although the character was created in 1923, the parade did not begin until 1929, when David Kellum initiated it as a celebration of the "unity in diversity for the children of Chicago". It has since grown to become a locally televised event and the second largest parade in the nation. The parade, which began on August 11, 1929,{{Cite web|url=http://budbillikenparade.com/history.htm|accessdate=September 17, 2007|date=2007|publisher=Chicago Defender Charities, Inc.|title=Bud Billiken: 78th Annual Parade and Picnic (Parade history)|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070917081357/http://budbillikenparade.com/history.htm |archivedate = September 17, 2007|deadurl=yes}} now includes politicians, beauty queens, celebrities, musical performers, and dozens of marching, tumbling and dancing groups. It has grown from a locally sponsored event to one with major corporate presence and is seen as a signal of the impending end of summer and beginning of the new school year. As such the parade sponsors raise money for college scholarships for local youth. The parade route has changed over the years. The original route was along [[Michigan Avenue (Chicago)|Michigan Avenue]] beginning at 31st Street, then turned east into Washington Park. Complaints for north-south traffic flow caused rerouting the parade route to South Parkway (now named Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive), which runs directly into the park. At various times, street repairs have necessitated use of the Michigan route, but the current route is now the King Drive route. [[Freeman Gosden]] and [[Charles Correll]] of ''[[Amos 'n' Andy]]'' were the first guests in the first parade. Robert S. Abbott led the first parade in his [[Rolls-Royce (car)|Rolls Royce]]. Dr. Marjorie Stewart Joyner, president of the Chicago Defender Charities, Inc., organized the parade for over 50 years. Numerous high-profile celebrities and dignitaries have attended the parade over the years, including U.S. President [[Harry S. Truman]],{{cite web |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1956/08/12/page/2/article/truman-leads-bud-billiken-day-marchers |title=Truman Leads Bud Billiken Day Marchers|date=August 12, 1956 |website= |publisher= Chicago Tribune |access-date=August 19, 2017 |quote=}} [[Michael Jordan]], [[Joe Louis]], [[Muhammad Ali]], [[Duke Ellington]], [[Adelaide Hall]],The 1933 Chicago World's Fair – Century of Progress, by Cheryl Ganz, published by University of Illinois Press, (January 6, 2012) {{ISBN|0252078527}}. Adelaide Hall, Cab Calloway and Earl Hines at the Bud Billiken parade and Picnic reference on page 115: https://books.google.com/books?id=GYXD8t4DDoIC&pg=PT163&dq=adelaide+hall+chicago&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tZdpU5vLI8a_ObH0gcgM&ved=0CGAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=adelaide%20hall%20chicago&f=false [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Diana Ross]], [[Lena Horne]], [[Ethel Waters]], [[Cab Calloway]], [[Paul Robeson]], [[Chaka Khan]] and [[Billie Holiday]]. Truman rode alongside John H. Sengstacke, who was Abbott's nephew and took over the ''Chicago Defender'' in 1948, and Mayor [[Richard J. Daley]] in the 1956 Parade.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/27/us/27defenders.html|title=Historical Trove, Freed From Storage, Gets a Home|accessdate=September 23, 2009|date=May 26, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Johnson, Dirk|page=A12}} Recent parades have featured popular musical acts as concert performers at the post-parade picnic. In 2006, approximately 26 million people saw the parade, including 25 million television viewers and 1.2 million attendees.{{Cite web|url=http://www.budbillikenparade.com/facts.htm|accessdate=July 4, 2007|date=2007|publisher=Chicago Defender Charities, Inc.|title=Bud Billiken: 78th Annual Parade and Picnic (Parade facts) |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060822035758/http://budbillikenparade.com/facts.htm |archivedate = August 22, 2006}} The 2006 parade included 74,000 participants and 160 floats and vehicles. The 2008 parade was dedicated to actor and comedian [[Bernie Mac]] (star of ''[[The Bernie Mac Show]]''){{Cite web|url=http://cbs2chicago.com/local/bernie.mac.dead.2.791473.html|title=Actor And Comedian Bernie Mac Dies At Age 50|last=Le Mignot|first=Suzanne|authorlink=Suzanne Le Mignot |date=August 9, 2008|publisher=CBS2Chicago|accessdate=August 10, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080822134830/http://cbs2chicago.com/local/bernie.mac.dead.2.791473.html |archivedate = August 22, 2008}} and a native of Chicago; he died an hour before the start of the parade. In 1993, a request by a black [[LGBT]] group to participate in the parade was declined by the organizers. Following legal action and the involvement of [[Lambda Legal]], the Ad Hoc Committee of Proud Black Lesbians and Gays was allowed to participate in the parade the following year.{{cite book|author=Tracy Baim|title=Out and Proud in Chicago: An Overview of the City's Gay Community|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aoLGAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA188|date=September 1, 2008|publisher=Surrey Books|isbn=978-1-57284-100-0|page=188}}{{cite book|last1=Ball|first1=Carlos A.|title=From the Closet to the Courtroom: Five LGBT Rights Lawsuits that Have Changed Our Nation|date=2010|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston, Mass|isbn=9780807001530|pages=79}} ===Broadcast=== The parade has been televised for over 35 years, beginning in 1978 on [[WGN-TV]]; which broadcast the parade until 2012. [[WCIU-TV]] covered the parade beginning in 2012 after it was canceled from WGN-TV but later canceled it in 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.tdogmedia.com/2012/08/wgn-tv-drops-bud-billiken-parade.html |title=WGN-TV drops Bud Billiken parade|date= August 8, 2012 |website=TDog Media |publisher= |access-date=August 20, 2016|quote=}} [[WLS-TV]] has been broadcasting the parade since 1984. The 89th Annual Parade took place on August 11, 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://abc7chicago.com/family/abc7s-broadcast-of-the-bud-billiken-parade/894144/|accessdate=August 11, 2015|date=August 7, 2015|publisher=[[WLS-TV]]|title=ABC7's broadcast of the Bud Billiken Parade}} [[BET]] and [[BET Her|Centric]] premiered the parade on their networks in 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.bet.com/news/celebrities/2012/09/07/bud-billiken-parade-premiere.html |title=Bud Billiken Parade Premiere|date=September 7, 2012|website= BET.COM |publisher= |access-date=August 1, 2013 |quote=}} ==Restructuring (2017)== The Chicago Defender Charities underwent a major restructuring in 2017. Myiti Sengstacke–Rice is Board President of the Chicago Defender Charities and Bud Billiken Parade Chair. Sengstacke–Rice is the great-grandniece of Robert Sengstacke Abbott, granddaughter of John Herman Henry Sengstacke, founder of the Chicago Defender Charities and daughter of the late famed photojournalist, Robert Abbott Sengstacke. ==Parade== [[File:ILLINOIS GOVERNOR DAN WALKER GREETS CHICAGO CONSTITUENTS DURING THE BUD BILLIKEN DAY PARADE, ONE OF THE LARGEST... - NARA - 556272.jpg|thumb|right|Illinois Governor [[Dan Walker (politician)|Dan Walker]] at the 1973 parade. Photo by [[John H. White (photojournalist)|John H. White]].]] The parade has categorized contests for participants such as best [[Float (parade)|float]], and best [[marching band]].{{Cite web|url=http://budbillikenparade.com/bestof.htm|title=Bud Billiken 78th Annual Parade and Picnic (Best of Parade)|accessdate=September 24, 2007|publisher=Chicago Defender Charities, Inc.|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080104120224/http://budbillikenparade.com/bestof.htm |archivedate = January 4, 2008|deadurl=yes}} It takes place in Chicago's [[Douglas, Chicago|Bronzeville]] neighborhood, starting at 35th Street {{cite web |url=https://www.timeout.com/chicago/things-to-do/bud-billiken-parade |title= (Chicago, Illinois) Things To Do - Bud Billiken Parade|date= July 29, 2015 |website= TimeOut |publisher= |access-date=August 3, 2015 |quote=}} and Dr. Martin Luther King Drive at the southern border of the [[Douglas, Chicago|Douglas]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]], south of the landmark [[Victory Monument (Chicago)|Victory Monument]]. It continues south to 55th Street in [[Washington Park, Chicago (park)|Washington Park]]. This route covers approximately {{convert|2|mi|km}}. This route takes the parade through the [[Grand Boulevard, Chicago|Grand Boulevard]] and [[Washington Park, Chicago (neighborhood)|Washington Park]] community areas. ===Theme=== Bud Billiken Parade is themed every year by the parade committee. The tradition began in 1940 when the parade organizers themed the parade "Americanism" to demonstrate patriotism in the US within the African-American community.{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eXI1CbKvCYEC&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=bud+billiken+parade+themes&source=bl&ots=leiFtGNTqf&sig=R1purQ2rJ1dUIjbNKKJu0o9Bt2A&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wGr-U4zyKpG0yATo2IK4DQ&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=bud%20billiken%20parade%20themes&f=false |title= Bud Billiken Parade|date=1979|website= Google Books |publisher= History of Black Chicago |access-date=November 7, 2012|quote=}} Other themes over the years: {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |+ Bud Billiken Parade Theme |- !
