{{italic title}} '''''Tilden Rent-A-Car Co. v. Clendenning''''' (1978), 83 DLR (3d) 400 is a leading [[Canadian contract law]] decision from the [[Court of Appeal for Ontario]] on [[standard form contract]]s. The Court held that a party can only be bound to a signed standard form contract when it is reasonable to believe that they consented to the terms.{{cite CanLII|year=1978|court=onca|num=1446|format=canlii}} ==Background== Clendenning rented a car from [[Tilden Rent-a-Car|Tilden Rent-A-Car]], a Canadian car rental company. He signed the rental agreement which contained an [[exclusion clause]] denying coverage for accidents that occur if the driver had consumed any alcohol. Later, Clendenning hit a pole after having consumed alcohol. He pleaded guilty to impaired driving and tried to collect from the insurance policy to pay for the damages of his accident. ==Opinion of the Court== Justice [[Charles Dubin]], for the court, held that Clendenning could collect from the insurance. Dubin observed that:
In modern commercial practice, many standard form printed documents are signed without being read or understood. In many cases the parties seeking to rely upon the terms of the contract know or ought to know that the signature of a party to the contract does not represent the true intention of the signer, and that the party signing is unaware of the stringent and onerous provisions which the standard form contains. Under such circumstances, I am of the opinion that the party seeking to rely on such terms should not be able to do so in the absence of first having taken reasonable measures to draw such terms to the attention of the other party, and, in the absence of such reasonable measures, it is not necessary for the party denying knowledge of such terms to prove either fraud, misrepresentation or [[non est factum]].p. 408-09
Normally, a customer would have time to consider the whole agreement. But in this particular situation, renters are typically in a rush and do not normally have a chance to read the terms of the agreement. The judge observed that the rental system is designed to be speedy and, therefore, lengthy and onerous terms cannot assumed to be assented to. ==See also== *[[Boilerplate contract]] ==Notes== [[Category:Canadian contract case law]] [[Category:1978 in Canadian case law]] [[Category:Car rental]] [[Category:Court of Appeal for Ontario cases]] [[Category:Driving under the influence]]

page.title: Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson

revision.comment: /* Royalty from reigning dynasties */clean up using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson |Image_Name = Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson.PNG |Image_Caption = Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark and Mary Donaldson on their wedding day. |AKA = |Participants = [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark]]
[[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Donaldson]] |Location = [[Copenhagen Cathedral]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] |Date = 14 May 2004 |Result = |URL = }} The '''wedding of [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark]], and [[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Donaldson]]''' took place on 14 May 2004 in the [[Copenhagen Cathedral]]. == Courtship and engagement == [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark]], and [[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Donaldson]] met on 16 September 2000, during the [[2000 Summer Olympics]] in [[Sydney]].;{{cite news|work=[[The Age]] |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/11/04/1036308258205.html |title=Sydney lass plays lady in waiting |date=5 November 2002 |accessdate=11 July 2012 |first=Jacquelin |last=Magnay}} Frederik identified himself as the [[Crown Prince of Denmark]] at the height of their courtship.{{cite news|url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/profiles/crown-princess-mary-of-denmark/ |title=Latest news and profile of Crown Princess Mary of Denmark |work=[[Hello (magazine)|Hello]] |accessdate=12 July 2012}} Their relationship was kept low-profile, although some Danish media reported the two were dating. On 24 September 2003, it was announced that Frederik's mother, [[Margrethe II of Denmark|Queen Margrethe II]], intended to give her consent to the marriage at the [[Danish Council of State|State Council]] meeting scheduled for 8 October 2003. Frederik and Mary became officially engaged on 8 October 2003. Frederik presented Mary with an engagement ring featuring an [[emerald cut]] [[diamond (gemstone)|diamond]] and two emerald cut [[ruby]] [[baguette cut|baguettes]].{{cite news|url=http://royalweddings.hellomagazine.com/prince-william-and-kate-middleton/galeria/20100922403/kate-middleton/prince-william/rings/1/5/#ancla |title=Crown jewels: The fabulous rings which sealed the love of Europe's royal couples |work=[[Hello (magazine)|Hello]] |accessdate=12 July 2012 |date=12 September 2010}} Prior to the wedding, Mary, who had previously been a dual citizen of [[Australia]] and the [[United Kingdom]], was granted Danish citizenship. She also converted from [[Presbyterianism]] to the [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] [[Church of Denmark]]. The media portrayed Frederik's and Mary's relationship as a modern "fairytale" romance between a prince and a commoner.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/14/1084289893038.html |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |title=So, this princess walks into a bar... |date=15 May 2004 |accessdate=12 July 2012 |first=Anthony |last=Dennis}} == Wedding ceremony == The wedding ceremony of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson was held on 14 May 2004 in the [[Copenhagen Cathedral]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]],{{cite news|url=http://kongehuset.dk/english/The-Royal-House/Crown-Prince-Couple |title=The Crown Prince Couple |accessdate=11 July 2012 |work=[[Danish Royal Family]]}} followed by the wedding festivities at the [[Fredensborg Palace]].{{cite news|work=[[Danish Royal Family]] |accessdate=11 July 2012 |title=HRH Crown Princess Mary |url=http://kongehuset.dk/english/The-Royal-House/Crown-Prince-Couple/HRH-Crown-Princess-Mary}} Mary's sisters Jane Stephens and Patricia Bailey, and her friend Amber Petty served as [[bridesmaids]], while Frederik's brother [[Prince Joachim of Denmark]] was the best man. Mary's nieces Erin and Kate Stephens and Madisson Woods were flower girls, and Frederik's nephew [[Prince Nikolai of Denmark]] and first cousin once removed [[Princess Alexandra of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg|Count Richard von Pfeil und Klein-Ellguth]] were pageboys. Mary wore a wedding dress created by Danish fashion designer Uffe Frank with a veil first used by [[Princess Margaret of Connaught|Crown Princess Margareta of Sweden]], and then by her daughter [[Ingrid of Sweden|Ingrid, Queen of Denmark]]. The veil, made from [[Irish lace]], was later worn by Ingrid's daughters [[Margrethe II of Denmark|Margrethe]], [[Princess Benedikte of Denmark|Benedikte]] and [[Queen Anne-Marie of Greece|Anne-Marie]]. Mary's wedding tiara was a gift from Queen Margrethe and [[Henrik, Prince Consort of Denmark|Prince Henrik]].{{cite news|url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/royalty/2004/07/30/marydonaldsongown/ |date=30 July 2004 |accessdate=12 July 2012 |title=Tradition and modernity in Mary's bridal ensemble |work=[[Hello (magazine)|Hello]]}} == Titles upon marriage == Upon her marriage, Mary embraced the title of her husband and became the [[Her Royal Highness]] [[Crown Prince of Denmark|Crown Princess of Denmark]]. Should Frederik eventually ascend to the Danish throne, as expected, Mary would automatically become the [[Queen consort]] of Denmark. She was also honoured with the [[Order of the Elephant]], and her father [[John Dalgleish Donaldson|John Donaldson]] with the grand cross of the [[Order of the Dannebrog]]. In accordance with the statutes of the [[Danish Royal Family|Danish Royal Orders]], both of them were granted a personal [[coat of arms]].{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldryaustralia.org/news_and_events.htm#denmark |title=New arms for Crown Prince Mary of Denmark |work=Australian Heraldry Society |accessdate=12 July 2012}} On 29 April 2008, Frederik and Mary were also created the Count and the Countess of Monpezat, which is a title that Frederik inherited from his father [[Henrik, Prince Consort of Denmark]].{{cite news|url=http://www.b.dk/danmark/monpezat-til-frederik-og-joachim |title=Monpezat til Frederik og Joachim |language=Danish |date=30 April 2008 |accessdate=12 July 2012 |work=[[Berlingske Tidende]]}} == Guest list == === Danish Royal Family === * [[Margrethe II of Denmark|The Queen]] and [[Henrik, Prince Consort of Denmark|Prince Consort of Denmark]], ''the groom's parents'' ** [[Prince Joachim of Denmark|Prince Joachim]] and [[Alexandra, Countess of Frederiksborg|Princess Alexandra of Denmark]], ''the groom's brother and sister-in-law'' *** [[Prince Nikolai of Denmark]], ''the groom's nephew'' *** [[Prince Felix of Denmark]], ''the groom's nephew'' * [[Princess Benedikte of Denmark|Princess Benedikte]] and [[Richard, 6th Prince of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg|Prince Richard of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg]], ''the groom's aunt and uncle'' ** [[Gustav, Hereditary Prince of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg|Hereditary Prince Gustav of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg]] ** [[Princess Alexandra of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg|Princess Alexandra, Countess von Pfeil und Klein-Ellguth]] and [[Count Jefferson von Pfeil und Klein-Ellguth]] *** Count Richard von Pfeil und Klein-Ellguth ** [[Princess Nathalie of Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg]] * [[Queen Anne-Marie of Greece|Queen Anne-Marie]] and [[Constantine II of Greece|King Constantine II of the Hellenes]], ''the groom's aunt and uncle'' ** [[Princess Alexia of Greece and Denmark|Princess Alexia, Mrs. Morales]] and Mr [[Carlos Morales Quintana|Carlos Morales]] ** [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece|Crown Prince Pavlos]] and [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Crown Princess Marie-Chantal of Greece]] ** [[Prince Nikolaos of Greece and Denmark]] ** [[Princess Theodora of Greece and Denmark]] ** Prince Philippos of Greece and Denmark * [[Princess Elisabeth of Denmark]], ''the groom's mother's cousin'' === Monpezat family === * Françoise Bardin, ''the groom's paternal aunt'' * Comte Étienne Laborde de Monpezat, ''the groom's paternal uncle'' * Comte Jean-Baptiste Laborde de Monpezat, ''the groom's paternal uncle'' * Maureville Beauvillain, ''the groom's paternal aunt'' === Donaldson family === * [[John Dalgleish Donaldson|John Donaldson]] and [[Susan Moody]], ''the bride's father and stepmother'' ** Jane Stephens and Craig Stephens, ''the bride's sister and brother-in-law'' ** Patricia Bailey and Scott Bailey, ''the bride's sister and brother-in-law'' ** John Donaldson and Leanne Donaldson, ''the bride's brother and sister-in-law'' * Peter Donaldson, ''the bride's paternal uncle'' * John Pugh, ''the bride's maternal uncle'' * Margaret Cunningham, ''the bride's paternal grandaunt'' === Royalty from reigning dynasties === * [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|The King]] and [[Queen Silvia of Sweden|Queen of Sweden]] ** [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|The Crown Princess of Sweden]] ** [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland]] ** [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland]] * [[Queen Sofía of Spain|The Queen of Spain]] ** [[Infanta Elena, Duchess of Lugo|The Duchess]] and [[Jaime de Marichalar|Duke of Lugo]] ** [[Infanta Cristina, Duchess of Palma de Mallorca|The Duchess]] and [[Iñaki Urdangarin|Duke of Palma de Mallorca]] ** [[Felipe VI of Spain|The Prince of Asturias]] and fiancée [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Letizia Ortiz]] * [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|The Queen of the Netherlands]] ** [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands|The Prince of Orange]] and [[Queen Máxima of the Netherlands|Princess Máxima of the Netherlands]] ** [[Prince and [[Queen Paola of Belgium|Queen of the Belgians]] ** [[Philippe of Belgium|The Duke]] and [[Queen Mathilde of Belgium|Duchess of Brabant]] ** [[Princess Astrid of Belgium, Archduchess of Braganza|Duchess of Braganza]] * [[Karim Aga Khan IV|The Aga Khan]] === Other distinguished guests === * [[Tarja Halonen]], President of Finland and her spouse [[Pentti Arajärvi|Dr. Pentti Arajärvi]] * [[Dorrit Moussaieff]], wife of the [[Ólafur Ragnar Grímsson|President of Iceland]] * [[Bernadette Chirac]], wife of the [[Jacques Chirac|President of France]] === Bridesmaids and flower girls, best {{Infobox Organization |name = World Innovation Summit for Education |image = WISE_LOGO.jpg |size = 200px |formation = 2009 |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |founded by = [[Qatar Foundation]] |headquarters = [[Doha]], [[Qatar]] |region_served = Worldwide |website = [http://www.wise-qatar.org/ www.wise-qatar.org]}}
The '''World Innovation Summit for Education''' ('''WISE''') is an international initiative aimed at transforming education through innovation. WISE was established by [[Qatar Foundation]] in 2009 under the patronage of its chairperson, Sheikha [[Mozah bint Nasser Al Missned|Mozah bint Nasser]].<ref name="kanani">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rahimkanani/2014/07/05/wise-the-global-platform-for-innovators-in-education/|title=WISE: The Global Platform For Innovators In Education|publisher=Forbes|author=Rahim Kanani|date=5 July 2014|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> With a biennial Summit held in [[Doha]], and a range of year-round initiatives, WISE's mission revolves around promoting new approaches to education and investigating new ways to manage education challenges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/who-we-are|title=About WISE|publisher=WISE Qatar|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
== The Biennial Summit == [[File:WISE 2012 – Panel on day 3.jpg|thumb|Panel participants in the 2012 WISE Summit.]] The 3-day WISE Summit is held every 2 years in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/about-summit|title=The WISE Summit|publisher=WISE Qatar|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> It unites over 1,500 experts, researchers, and innovators from multiple sectors worldwide to foster new collaborations and develop solutions with the goal of inspiring creative changes in education. The summit is currently organized by Stavros Yiannouka and his team. Each summit has a distinct theme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.com/2014/10/30/follow-live-wise-summit-november-4-6-creativity-at-the-heart-of-education/|title=(As it happened) Imagine, Create, Learn: reinventing education at WISE summit 2014|publisher=Euronews|date=30 October 2014|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> The first summit was held in 2009 under the theme "Global Education: Working Together for Sustainable Achievements".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/2009-summit-global-education-working-together-sustainable-achievements|title=The 2009 World Innovation Summit for Education (WISE) convened November 16-18, in Doha, Qatar under the theme "Global Education: Working Together for Sustainable Achievements"|publisher=WISE Qatar|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
==The WISE Prize for Education== The WISE Prize for Education is an international prize that rewards an individual or a team for contributions to education which have been adjudged to be outstanding. The inaugural edition was launched in 2011 with a monetary award of $500,000.<ref name="coughlan2013">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-24727690|title=Colombia school project founder wins global prize|publisher=BBC|author=Sean Coughlan|date=29 October 2013|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
Selection criteria for the prize stipulates that the laureate’s work should have had a significant and lasting impact at any level of education. The laureate is selected by an international jury of education stakeholders and announced at the annual Summit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/wise-prize-for-education|title=The WISE Prize for Education|publisher=WISE Qatar|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
The first WISE Prize was awarded to [[Fazle Hasan Abed]], founder and chairman of [[BRAC (NGO)|BRAC]] (Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/media/media_60534.html|title=WISE prize for education goes to Bangladeshi Sir Fazle Hasan Abed|publisher=UNICEF|date=16 November 2011|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> The second prize, in 2012, went to [[Madhav Chavan]], co-founder and CEO of India-based NGO [[Pratham]].<ref name="coughlan2013"/> The third WISE Prize laureate, announced at the 2013 Summit, was [[Vicky Colbert]], founder and director of Fundacion Escuela Nueva in Colombia.<ref name="coughlan2013"/> [[Ann Cotton]], an advocate of girls' education, was awarded the 2014 prize.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-29880500|title=UK girls' education campaigner wins global prize|publisher=BBC|author=Sean Coughlan|date=4 November 2014|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> Dr. [[Sakena Yacoobi]] was awarded the 2015 prize.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-34721680|title=Afghan education campaigner wins global prize|last=Coughlan|first=Sean|date=2015-11-04|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en-GB}}</ref>Most recently, the 2017 prize was awarded<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ashesi.edu.gh/stories-and-events/2546-wise-prize-for-education-2017-presented-to-ashesi-founder-patrick-awuah.html|title=WISE Prize for Education 2017 presented to Ashesi Founder, Patrick Awuah|website=www.ashesi.edu.gh|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/people/interview-patrick-awuah|title=Interview with Patrick Awuah|date=2018-01-04|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en}}</ref> to the founder and president of [[Ashesi University|Ashesi Universit]]<nowiki/>y in Ghana, [[Patrick Awuah Jr.|Dr. Patrick Awuah]].
==Other activities==
===[[The WISE Awards]]=== Each year [[the WISE Awards]] recognize and promotes six projects that address global educational challenges. A pre-jury composed of education experts assesses submissions and selects a shortlist of fifteen finalists. Following this, a jury chooses the six award-winning projects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/Mobile/Qatar/178/details/455191/Al-Bairaq-is-among-six-WISE-Awards-winners|title=Al-Bairaq is among six WISE Awards winners|publisher=Gulf Times|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> Winners receive a cash prize of $20,000. The first WISE Awards were handed out in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iie.org/en/Who-We-Are/News-and-Events/Events/2013/WISE-2013|title=IIE Partners with Qatar Foundation on World Innovation Summit on Education 2013|publisher=Institute of International Education|date=30 October 2013|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Award Year !! !! !! !! !! !! |- |2016 |Education for Growth and Value Creation in Lebanon |Geekie: Personalized Learning for All |Ideas Box |JUMP Math |Little Ripples: Culturally Inspired Pre-School |Tara Akshar Literacy Program |- | 2015 || [[Al-Bairaq]] || [[Bridge International Academies]] || Nafham || [[Educate! (nonprofit)|Educate!]] || The Talking Book Program || VideoBook for Deaf Children |- | 2014 || Alternate Education for Rural Development in Peru || Me and My City || We Love Reading || The Song Room || Street Children: Re-integration through Education || [[Educate Girls]] |- | 2013 || [[Alison (company)|Alison]] || iThra Youth Initiative || Medersat.com || Pathways to Education || PEAS || Te Kotahitanga |- | 2012 || [[Cristo Rey Network]] Corporate Work Study Program || PSU Educarchile || [[RoboBraille]] || Satya Bharti School Program || Solar-Powered Floating Schools || [[Cambodian Children's Fund]] Generational Change through Education |- | 2011 || [[BBC Janala]] || [[OpenStax CNX]] || [[Creative Partnerships]] || School-Business Partnerships || SueñaLetras || Teacher Education in Sub Saharan Africa (TESSA) |- | 2010 || [[The Citizens Foundation]] || Mother Child Education program (MOCEP) || The Smallholder Farmers Rural Radio || [[MIT OpenCourseWare]] || [[NextEinstein]] Initiative (AIMS-NEI) || Rewrite the Future |- | 2009 || [[Project Nanhi Kali]] || Escuela Nueva || [[Curriki]] || Distance Learning in the Amazon Forest || The Financially Sustainable School || Widows Alliance Network (WANE) |}
=== The WISE Research Series === The WISE Research Reports bring key topics to the forefront of the global education debate, and reflect the priorities of the Qatar National Research Strategy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/2015-wise-research|title=2015 WISE Research|work=www.wise-qatar.org|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en}}</ref>
===WISE Books=== WISE Books are aimed at supporting innovative thinking in education. As of October 2014, WISE has published three books addressing educational topics. WISE Book authors and photographers travel to several countries in an attempt to identify the challenges and illustrate the impact of initiatives and practices that are making tangible differences. The third book to be released by WISE, ''Learning (Re)Imagined - How the connected society is transforming learning'' focuses on the link between technology and education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/news/qatar/302719/wise-releases-third-book-on-education|title=WISE releases third book on education|publisher=The Peninsula|date=6 October 2014|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
===WISE Learners' Voice=== Learners' voice, inaugurated in 2010, is a program that aims to reshape students' perception of education. Each year, a selected group of young people, aged 18–25, participate at the annual summit by engaging in debates and making presentations. Workshop sessions are also held throughout the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lancaster.ac.uk/enterprisecentre/learners-voice/|title=WISE Learners’ Voice Program for Educational Innovators|publisher=Lancaster University|author=Francesca Green|date=16 March 2015|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> In late 2013, 36 new learners joined the existing network of 78 learners from previous years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naylornetwork.com/iie-nwl/articles/index.asp?aid=221307&issueID=30449|title=Qatar Foundation's WISE Learners' Voice: Call for Nomination|publisher=Institute of International Education|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
===WISE Accelerator=== The accelerator is a support and advisory program with the aim of developing early-stage projects in education. The program, founded in 2014, seeks to assist projects that have a high potential for scalability and a positive impact on the field of education.<ref name="kanani"/> The program selects five innovative projects from a variety of countries every year.
The past participants of the program, including country of origin and date of creation:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/wise-accelerator-program|title=2014-15 Program|publisher=|accessdate=5 January 2018}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year of participation !! Name !! Country !! Date of creation |- | ''2014-2015'' || Ideas Box || France || 2013 |- | || Kytabu Textbook Subscription || Kenya || 2012 |- | || Mobile Taleem || Pakistan || 2012 |- | || Sterio.me || Chile || 2013 |- | || Ustad Mobile || United Arab Emirates || 2012 |- | ''2015-2016'' || eduTechnoz || Canada || 2012 |- | || [[Kepler (institution)|Kepler]] || United States || 2013 |- | || Making Ghanaian Girls Great! || United Kingdom || 2014 |- | || Maths Curriculum Online || South Africa || 2010 |- | || [[TeachPitch]] || United Kingdom || 2014 |- |''2016-2017'' |Aflatoun Education |The Netherlands |2014 |- | |Chalk.com |Canada |2013 |- | |Edukasyon.ph |Philippines |2013 |- | |Joko's World |Australia |2013 |- | |Learn Syria |Canada |2013 |}
==Partners== The WISE initiative has cooperation agreements with the following institutions in major education issues: [[:fr:Agence universitaire de la Francophonie|Agence universitaire de la Francophonie]] (AUF), the [[Association of Commonwealth Universities]] (ACU), the [[Institute of International Education]] (IIE), the [[International Association of University Presidents]] (IAUP), [[RAND Corporation]], and the [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iie.org/en/Who-We-Are/News-and-Events/Press-Center/Press-Releases/2014/2014-11-13-5th-Annual-Wise|title=The 5th Annual WISE Program for Education Leadership|format=Press release|website=iie.org|date=13 November 2014|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
